title: 105_s2545
content: The "Medicare HMO Protection Act of 1998" allows for the evaluation and alteration of termination decisions. The Social Security Act allows the Secretary to delay the termination of a Medicare+Choice plan if it poses a serious health risk, reduces plan availability, or if the terminating organization is not offering alternative coverage. The Secretary can delay the termination of a Medicare+Choice plan if it results in a significant reduction in plan availability or if the terminating organization offers plans in nearby areas without suffering financial losses. The Secretary may audit the organization's books to make this determination. The Secretary has the authority to delay the termination of a Medicare+Choice plan if an adequate provider network is established to maintain insurance coverage levels. If the termination is delayed, the Secretary and the organization may renegotiate the contract. The Secretary can delay termination of a Medicare+Choice plan if a provider network is established to maintain coverage levels. During this period, the Secretary and the organization can renegotiate a new contract to continue coverage without adversely affecting beneficiaries. SEC. 3. Extension of initial Medicare+Choice contract period to 3 years. Amends the Social Security Act to require contracts to have a term of at least 3 years. Effective for contracts entered into after the date of enactment. SEC. 4. Notice of termination. Section 1857(d)(3) of the Social Security Act is amended to require organizations to provide written notice 120 days before terminating a contract, including information on alternative Medicare+Choice plans and supplemental policies available in the area. The Social Security Act now requires organizations to give 120 days written notice before terminating a contract, including details on alternative Medicare+Choice plans, supplemental policies, and local social service agencies for assistance. This amendment applies to termination notices provided after the enactment of this Act.
